The '''petro''', or ''petromoneda'',<ref name="NPR"/> is a [[cryptocurrency]] proposed to be adopted by [[Venezuela]].<ref>[https://papers.ssrn.com/sol3/papers.cfm?abstract_id=3119606 Cryptocurrencies as Asset-Backed Instruments: The Venezuelan Petro]. ''Banking and Insurance eJournal.'' Social Science Research Network (SSRN). Accessed 18 February 2018.</ref> Announced in December 2017, it would be backed by the country's [[Oil reserves in Venezuela|oil]] and [[Mining in Venezuela|mineral reserves]], and it is intended to supplement Venezuela's [[Venezuelan bolívar|bolivar fuerte]] currency as a means of circumventing [[United States embargoes|U.S.]] [[economic sanctions|sanctions]] and access international financing. Petros will be "pre-mined", meaning that new tokens cannot be created after the issuance, and are likely to be a token on the [[Ethereum]] network.<ref name="helms"/>

==History==

Venezuelan President [[Nicolás Maduro]] announced the petro in a televised address on 3 December 2017, stating that it would be backed by Venezuela's reserves of [[petroleum|oil]], [[gasoline]], [[gold]], and [[diamond]]s.<ref name="NYT">{{cite news |url= https://www.nytimes.com/2017/12/03/world/americas/venezuela-cryptocurrency-maduro.html|title=Venezuela Plans a Cryptocurrency, Maduro Says|work=[[The New York Times]]|date=3 December 2017|accessdate=2017-12-03}}</ref><ref name="Reuters">{{cite news|url=https://www.reuters.com/article/us-venezuela-economy/enter-the-petro-venezuela-to-launch-oil-backed-cryptocurrency-idUSKBN1DX0SQ|title=Enter the 'petro': Venezuela to launch oil-backed cryptocurrency|last=Ulmer|first=Alexandra|author2=Deisy Buitrago|work=[[Reuters]]|date=3 December 2017|accessdate=2017-12-03}}</ref>

Maduro stated that the petro would allow Venezuela to "advance in issues of [[monetary sovereignty]]",<ref>[https://papers.ssrn.com/sol3/papers.cfm?abstract_id=3079241 "Monetary Sovereignty: International Political Economy: Monetary Relations eJournal"], ''Cryptoanarchism and Cryptocurrencies.'' Social Science Research Network (SSRN). Date accessed 23 January 2018.</ref> and that it would make "new forms of international financing" available to the country.<ref name="NYT"/> [[Democratic Unity Roundtable|Opposition]] leaders, however, expressed doubt due to [[Economy of Venezuela#2013–present|Venezuela's economic turmoil]],<ref name="Reuters"/> pointing to the [[Currency appreciation and depreciation|falling value]] of the [[Venezuelan bolívar]], its [[fiat currency]], and $140 billon in foreign debt.<ref name="BBC">{{cite news|url= http://www.bbc.com/news/world-latin-america-42217798|title=Venezuela unveils virtual currency amid economic crisis|work =[[BBC]] |date=3 December 2017|accessdate=2017-12-03}}</ref>

On January 5, 2018, Maduro announced that Venezuela would issue 100 million tokens of the petro,<ref>{{cite news|last1=Gupta|first1=Girish|title=Maduro says Venezuela will issue $5.9 billion in oil-backed cryptocurrency |url= https://www.reuters.com/article/us-venezuela-economy/maduro-says-venezuela-will-issue-5-9-billion-in-oil-backed-cryptocurrency-idUSKBN1EV02S|accessdate=8 February 2018|work=Reuters|date=5 January 2018}}</ref> which would put the value of the entire issuance at just over $6 billion.<ref>{{cite news|title=Venezuela Parliament Calls President’s $5.9 bln Petro Cryptocurrency ‘New Fraud’|url=https://cointelegraph.com/news/venezuela-parliament-calls-presidents-59-bln-petro-cryptocurrency-new-fraud|agency=Cointelegraph|date=10 January 2018}}</ref> It also established a cryptocurrency government advisory group called VIBE to act as "an institutional, political and legal base" from which to launch the petro.<ref name="NPR">{{cite news|url= https://www.npr.org/sections/thetwo-way/2017/12/04/568299704/venezuela-will-create-new-petro-cryptocurrency-president-maduro-says|title=Venezuela Will Create New 'Petro' Cryptocurrency, President Maduro Says|last=Chappell|first=Bill|work=[[National Public Radio]]|date=4 December 2017|accessdate=2017-12-05}}</ref> Carlos Vargas is the "Superintendent of Cryptocurrencies".<ref name="helms">{{cite news|last1=Helms|first1=Kevin|title=Venezuela Considers Selling Its ”Oil-Backed” Cryptocurrency With a 60% Discount |url= https://news.bitcoin.com/venezuela-considers-selling-its-oil-backed-cryptocurrency-with-a-60-discount |accessdate=8 February 2018|work=Bitcoin News| date=17 January 2018}}</ref>

In a document leaked to and reviewed by [[Reuters]], VIBE recommended that the government sell $2.3 billion worth of petros in a private offering at a discount of up to 60%, indicating that "Maduro’s valuation of the nascent petro faces significant market skepticism", followed by $2.7 billion worth of petros offered to the public a month later, with the remainder "shared between the government and VIBE". It also suggested that the government accept tax payments in petros as well as allow [[PDVSA]], the country's state-owned oil company, incorporate cryptocurrencies in its dealings with foreign companies.<ref name="lesley"/> The petro’s pre-sale will take place from Feb. 20 at -04:00 UTC to Mar. 19 at -04:00 UTC, and there will be 38.4 mln tokens available.<ref>{{cite news|title=Venezuela’s Cryptocurrency Petro Finds Foreign Investors, ICO To Take Place In March|url=https://cointelegraph.com/news/venezuelas-cryptocurrency-petro-finds-foreign-investors-ico-to-take-place-in-march|agency=Cointelegraph|date=8 February 2018}}</ref><ref>{{cite web
 |url= http://www.bbc.com/news/live/business-42850644
 |title= Venezuela presses ahead with Petro
 |access-date = February 20, 2018
 |last= Gallas
 |first= Daniel
 |date= January 30, 2018
 |website= [[BBC]]
 |language = english
 |quote= Venezuela is to start selling its cryptocurrency “Petro” next month. In a meeting with cabinet ministers, President Nicolas Maduro (above) said it will launch the currency on 20 February.
 |format= html
 |archive-url= https://web.archive.org/web/20180220093417/http://www.bbc.com/news/live/business-42850644
 |archive-date= February 20, 2018
}}</ref>

==Response==

In response, Venezuela’s [[National Assembly (Venezuela)|National Assembly]], run by the opposition [[Democratic Unity Roundtable]], declared the petro to be an illegal debt issuance by a government desperate for cash, and has said it will not recognize it.<ref name="lesley">{{cite news| last1= Wroughton | first1=Lesley|title=U.S. warns investors over Venezuela's 'petro' cryptocurrency|url=https://www.reuters.com/article/us-venezuela-economy-cryptocurrency/u-s-warns-investors-over-venezuelas-petro-cryptocurrency-idUSKBN1F52AB|accessdate=8 February 2018|work=Reuters|date=16 January 2018}}</ref>

In the [[United States]], the [[U.S. Department of the Treasury|Department of the Treasury]] warned that participating in Venezuela's proposed [[initial coin offering]] for the petro cryptocurrency could violate [[United States embargoes|U.S. sanctions]] against Venezuela, because it "would appear to be an extension of credit to the Venezuelan government".<ref name="lesley"/>

The cryptocurrency community's response was mixed yet generally negative. Cryptocurrency expert [[Max Keiser]] expressed his support in light of the country's [[hyperinflation]],<ref name="iib">{{cite news|last1=Adams|first1=Colin|title=Meet the “Petro”, Venezuela’s New “Cryptocurrency”|url=https://www.investinblockchain.com/venezuela-cryptocurrency-petro/|accessdate=8 February 2018|work=Invest in Blockchain|date=14 December 2017}}</ref> while economist [[Jean Paul Leidenz]] expressed concerns that the creation of the petro would encourage further hyperinflation.<ref name="NPR"/> ''[[Forbes]]''{{'}}s [[Steve Hanke]] stated that the petro was likely to wind up "in the graveyard".<ref>{{cite news|url=https://www.forbes.com/sites/stevehanke/2017/12/06/maduros-petro-will-join-chavezs-bolivar-fuerte-in-the-graveyard/|title=Maduro's 'Petro' Cryptocurrency Will Join Chavez's Bolivar Fuerte, In The Graveyard|last=Hanke|first=Steve|date=6 December 2017|work=Forbes|accessdate=2017-12-11|location=New York}}</ref>
